body.p: THE
ISRAELITE.
BLOCH & CO., Publishers.
CINCINNATI, OHIO....................DECEMBER 4, 1868.
THE MYSTERIES OF GENERAL GRANT'S
ORDER No. 11.

After a letter of General Grant himself on
the subject of Order No. 11 has been pub-
lished in this journal by his own consent,
and the election being over, and no charge
of making political capital can be pre-
ferred against us—we consider it a duty to
state what we know about the matter, and
this will explain the General's letter.

The statement to which the General re-
fers, as having been made out for publica-
tion, relates, most likely, to the substance
of a conversation which Mr. Eckstein of
Cincinnati had with the General, and which
Mr. E. reduced to writing, with the General's
consent. Mr. Eckstein did not publish the
matter, because he considered the publica-
tion impolitic. His motives were honora-
ble, and entirely in favor of General Grant.

At the same time we were put on the
track to ascertain, beyond the shadow of a
doubt, the origin of Order No. 11. Our
readers must remember the mean spirit
against the Jews which manifested itself in
Washington from and after the outbreak
of the rebellion. From Senator Wilson
down to the agent of the associated press,
speakers and writers belittled and slan-
dered the Jew on numerous occasions, in
the style of Brownlow and Butler. Those
who forgot this, can refresh their memory
by reviewing the pages of THE ISRAELITE
from 1861 to 1864. Mr. Benjamin of Louis-
iana is a Jew, therefore—"never mind, the
Jew must be burnt." This was the style
of the accusation and the argument.
Therefore nothing in the world was easier
than to cast a slur on the Jew anywhere. It
was done with perfect impunity; it became
fashionable among upstarts and toadies.
THE ISRAELITE was the only organ which
raised its voice against that iniquity,
and THE ISRAELITE had enemies enough to
decry its tendency. The reader must bear
in mind, that this was the spirit of the age
in Washington at that time, in order to un-
derstand the sequel.

With the advance of our armies in the
South-west, the cotton trade began to claim
the attention of speculators. Some promi-
nent gentlemen in Washington, senators
and high officials, whose names we know,
but do not wish to mention, were the first
and most extensive cotton dealers at the
time, and realized vast profits from the
trade. Some Jewish houses in the West
discovered the opportunity, and went into
the cotton trade. This was an unpleasant
opposition to the Washington operators,
for the Jews paid higher prices, bought
the cotton up, and the speculators down on
them. It must not be forgotten, however,
that the Jews did not purchase one-tenth
of the cotton which was sold there along
the line; nevertheless the Washington oper-
ators did not like the interference.

Nothing was easier at that time than to
play chicaneries on the Jew. It was given
out there, the Jews smuggle gold across the
line to purchase cotton of the rebels, and
everybody was ready to believe it, and to
add in explanation, "All the Jews buy all
the cotton, and all of them smuggle all all the
gold." This was a master stroke of the
Washington operators, for it led to secret
instructions from head-quarters to all the
commanders in the West, to look out after
the Jews. Our readers must remember all
the chicaneries to which they were sub-
jected in Louisville, Bowling Green, Nash-
ville and elsewhere, outside of General
Grant's department. Every feeling of
honor was outraged by provost marshals,
post commanders, aids, corporals and de-
tectives, and all that was done chiefly on
instigation of the Washington cotton spec-
ulators. General Grant then issued an or-
der, that no cotton should be bought for
gold, in order to prevent carrying gold
across the line; but the order was revoked
in Washington, because it interfered with
the cotton speculators there, who knew
that people on the line would not take
greenbacks, and their agents carried the
gold precisely to the same places where the
Jews did. Neither of them considered it
very sinful to purchase cotton anywhere,
and for any sort of money.

All these chicaneries and outrages, how-
ever, did not terrify Jewish traders along
the line, especially in General Grant's de-
partment, where most of the cotton was.
This set the Washington operators to work
against General Grant. They accused him
of mal-administration, maintaining that
most of the smuggling was done in his de-
partment, and even insinuated that he did
not care exactly to stop it. They had an
anonymous letter to this effect written and
mailed at Chicago to the war office in
Washington, and there the nameless letter
was so seriously taken to heart, that it was
forwarded to General Grant with the repri-
mand which, the General says, "incensed"
him. Just think, how vigilantly the war
office watched over the interests of the
country, if an anonymous letter even was
so carefully considered, that it was for-
warded to a commanding General with a
reprimand. If there had been no cotton
dealers somewhere not quite a hundred
miles from that office, that anonymous let-
ter must surely have taken its regular
course into the waste paper basket. It is
common for thieves to cry: catch the thief.

They understood the art very well how to
incense General Grant, and knowing that
they had brought him to the point, rapidly
and sagaciously followed up their victory
to earn the fruits. On the 17th of Decem-
ber, 1862, General Grant, at Oxford, Miss.,
received the following instruction from
Washington:

"We are reliably informed that the Jews
in the various cities are buying up the gold,
to take to the South, to invest in cotton—that
will place in the hands of the rebels in-
creased means to carry on the war. That
should be prevented. You will therefore
take measures to prevent it in your depart-
ment."

The natural consequence of this peremp-
tory instruction, after the previous ex-
pression from head-quarters, was the issue
of Order No. 11, exiling the Jews from the
department of the Tennessee. At the same
time, however, Jews not connected anyway
with the General, applied and received per-
mission to remain, as he himself did actu-
ally not know against whom, personally,
the order was directed. It was a general
outrage committed in military obedience
and subordination to orders from head-
quarters, in consequence especially of the
former reprimand.

The order came from Washington, and,
like former orders and instructions, was
procured by the cotton ring. But it is evi-
dent, that some cabinet officers worked
harmoniously with the said ring.

A few hours after that order had been
issued, we were informed thereof, and pub-
lished it in THE ISRAELITE. Five days be-
fore publishing it, however, (it appeared
Friday, January 2,) we wrote a letter to
Secretary Stanton, apprising him of the
outrageous order, and suggested very po-
litely, that the order should be instantly
revoked before any complaints could reach
Washington, which would place the Gov-
ernment in the best light. We quoted his-
torical precedences in support of the sug-
gestion, and finally begged the Secretary
to save us the unpleasant business of going
to Washington to request the President
to revoke the order, as we should be unable
to resist the pressure—and would have to
go. Our object was to place the Govern-
ment in a proper light, and to prevent any
and every notoriety of the said order, which
we apprehended was fraught with mischief.
Reluctantly we published the order, ex-
pecting to the last moment an answer by
the Secretary, or the revocation of the or-
der; but neither came.

A delegation was elected to see the Presi-
dent on the subject. On the 7th of Janu-
ary, in the evening, we were introduced to
President Lincoln, who informed us that
the order was revoked yesterday. He
said, especially and literally: "I could not
imagine that Grant could have issued such
a foolish order. I sent over to Stanton, and
to Halleck, (January 5,) and they did not
know anything about it."

Now mark, Mr. Stanton knew nothing
about the existence of that order on Janu-
ary 5, 1863; although we had written him
the whole affair in December, and a letter
reaches Washington from Cincinnati in less
than two days; and although the text to
the order came from his very department,
and the order was issued on the 17th of
December; and although the anonymous
letter from Chicago—so much importance
was attached to letters—the anonymous
letter accusing the Jews, was sent with a
reprimand to General Grant.

You know now who conspired with the
cotton ring in Washington? You know
who issued the text to Grant's Order No.
11? You know now who were the swin-
dlers and the lazaroni of the army? If
you do not know it, we do, and in order
that the reader may also know it, we will
add one more fact: After Grant's Order
No. 11 had been issued, and the ring be-
lieved to have finally disposed of all small
traders, (they did not imagine a revocation
possible,) the text to another general order
came from the self-same department, and
this was, that COTTON MUST BE SOLD FOR
TWENTY-FIVE CENTS A POUND. You know
now, who were the thieves, the smugglers
and the lazaroni? We hope you do.

We have done justice to the case, and
despise, from the deepest depth of our soul
we despise and condemn those small, filthy
and shameless office seekers, who impugned
our motives in public print, as was done
by persons who, for the last eight years,
were in market for any and every appoint-
ment, as they could not venture their
names on an election. We owe like com-
pliments to those of our habitual traducers
who, not withstanding the articles that ap-
peared in this journal prior to the assem-
bling of the Chicago Convention were only
designed toward dissuading the party from
nominating Grant while we still believed
him the author of Order No. 11, notwith-
standing the publication by us of political
articles against Grant ceased with the as-
sembling and adjournment of the Chicago
Convention, still persisted in wantonly
and recklessly accusing the editor of seek-
ing to subvert the purposes of THE ISRAEL-
ITE to partisan ends, and of seeking a mar-
ket for whatever of political influence we
might have been able to exert. We will
mention no names, they are too insignifi-
cant.

The question is asked, why did not Gen.
Grant come out in bold language, and say
the same things? We venture to say, you
lay this document before the General, and
he will subscribe to every word thereof.
We furthermore assert, that we have our
information from as direct a source as pos-
sible. Nevertheless every reader must ad-
mit, that a General will not blame his
former superiors. The matter has been
brought to our knowledge, and justice re-
quires its publication.
